text.text:
Tucked right along bustling Orchard Road, Masjid Angullia is a serene escape from the fast pace of the city. This mosque may not be large, but it holds great historical and spiritual significance, being one of the oldest mosques in Singapore, established in the late 1800s.

The prayer hall is simple yet dignified, with good air circulation and well-kept amenities. Ablution areas are clean and conveniently located.

You can often find travelers stopping by for prayers or to admire the historic architecture.

Accessibility: Very easy to reach – just a short walk from Orchard MRT station. It’s a convenient stop for Muslim shoppers or tourists needing a nearby place for prayer.

Angullia Mosque beautifully balances tradition and accessibility. It's a spiritual gem amidst the modernity of Singapore’s shopping belt.

text.text:
Angulia mosque bears a historical significance from 1800s. It is the part of century old history of them compongs of united tribes from China, Malay, Indian and Arab visitors coming to the island.
The location is at the heart of current times little Indian ecosystem and heritage. It's reachable from the long merchants market spreading from across Tekka Market till Mustafa Mall.
Walking steps from the mall it serves hundreds of Muslims who offer to prayers whether the visitors or people living or working nearby.
Architecture is being revamped however, glimpses of historic building kept intact at the entrance area so people get to know it's history
Multi story and separate space for men and women. Has lift available to reach upstairs.

text.text: Awesome masjid with ample space for worshippers. We were there for Jummah. The sermon was in Tamil by the translation in English was on TV screens across. Great atmosphere too. Also has a roof top open prayer room.

originalText.text: Awesome masjid with ample space for worshippers. We were there for Jummah. The sermon was in Tamil by the translation in English was on TV screens across. Great atmosphere too. Also has a roof top open prayer room.

text.text:
Tucked away in the vibrant streets of Little India, Singapore, the Angullia Mosque stands as a testament to the enduring legacy of the Angullia family, one of the oldest Gujarati Muslim families in the country. Established in 1890 by merchant and philanthropist Mohammed Salleh Eusoff Angullia, the mosque was built to serve the growing Muslim community in the area. Over the years, it has undergone several renovations, evolving from a simple place of worship to a modern mosque while maintaining its historical significance. Little India, known for its rich cultural tapestry, is an unexpected yet fitting home for a mosque that reflects Singapore’s diverse heritage. Surrounded by bustling markets, temples, and shophouses, Angullia Mosque continues to be a spiritual refuge amid the liveliness of the district. Today, it stands as not only a place of prayer but also a symbol of the contributions of early Indian-Muslim traders in shaping Singapore’s multicultural identity.

The story of Indian migration extends far beyond Singapore. Under British colonial rule, millions of Indians were sent across the world as laborers, traders, and administrators, leaving a lasting impact in places thousands of miles from their homeland. Hindi is still spoken today in Fiji, an island nation over 11,600 km (7,200 miles) from India, as a result of indentured laborers being taken there in the 19th century. Meanwhile, in South America, Guyana—a country where nearly one-quarter of the population is Muslim—has a sitting president of Indian Muslim descent, Irfaan Ali, whose roots trace back to Uttar Pradesh. Guyana itself is over 14,000 km (8,700 miles) from India, yet the cultural and religious ties remain strong, a testament to how migration has shaped Muslim communities across the world. The Indian diaspora’s journey is one of resilience, adaptation, and the preservation of faith and culture, with places like Angullia Mosque standing as reminders of these enduring connections.

#ramadan30days30mosques #ramadan #mosque #mosques #ramadanchallenge #islam #muslim #holymonth #tourism #travel #singapore #bangladeshi

text.text: Prayed here after Iftar. The women’s area is on the 3rd floor and very spacious. The entry is from the parking behind.
